params.text: Courtesy of Spongebob Squarepants
By tujuh17belas
What’s the Difference Between Misinformation and Disinformation?

The best way to combat false information is to understand the motivations behind why these are created and shared. You may have already heard the terms “misinformation”, “disinformation”, and “fake news” before. While they overlap in meaning, we can categorize how information is used based on their definitions.
By tujuh17belas
By Olgadesigner
Fill in the missing words. Use lowercase letters.

questions: The term *disinformation * is described when false information is spread to deliberately mislead or manipulate narratives.
It is considered *fake news* if it was purposefully designed in a way that mimics mainstream news media.
When a person shares a piece of false information, without manipulative or malicious intent, it is said to be *misinformation*.

params.text:
Why Do People Fall for Fake News?

When it comes to processing new information, humans tend to focus on understanding the message and deciding what to do next instead of evaluating its accuracy (American Psychological Association, 2023). This can make us more susceptible to falling for false information presented in the media.
By N-Universe

metadata.title: Why Do People Fall for Fake News?

metadata.title: Nancy Franklin on Cognition & Audience Bias

params.text:
Nancy Franklin on Cognition & Audience Bias

Video Courtesy of Center For News Literacy

Access here: https://youtu.be/deSQlS0wA0M?si=nD8RC-K9-iT9cdo4
Fake or Real: Tips for Evaluating Digital Content

Fake websites typically use URLs that sound legitimate but aren’t. Check the domain name closely before liking or sharing a post. 

For example, a study discussing the psychology of misinformation posted by the official website of the American Psychological Association (https://www.apa.org/) is more reliable than an article posted on a personal blog with a URL like https://www.psychology-news.blogger.com/.

Check the source directly, and read their “About Us” page. Who runs the site? What’s their mission? Are the authors related to a certain company, group, or organization? Don’t trust anonymous sources.

Did you click on the video or article from your social media account’s news feed? Check what other high-quality news sources are saying about the topic. Your algorithm may be confirming your own biases instead of providing you a balanced view on the topic.

Consult an independent fact-checking site like FactCheck.org and Tsek.ph.

panels.title: Verify the validity of a story

params.text: Sometimes old news is reposted on social media to appear like current events. Check when the piece was published and if it has been updated since.

Did the video or article make you feel angry or frustrated? Pause and reflect on it before deciding to share it. Most fake news publishers want you to have an emotional reaction to their content. Do your own investigation and cross-reference the information they presented.

panels.title: Be critical of emotionally charged content

metadata.title: Fake or Real: Tips for Evaluating Digital Content

params.text: By master1305

Caceres, M. M. F., Sosa, J. P., Lawrence, J. A., Sestacovschi, C., Tidd-Johnson, A., Rasool, M. H. U., Gadamidi, V. K., Ozair, S., Pandav, K., Cuevas-Lou, C., Parrish, M., Rodriguez, I., & Fernandez, J. P. (2022). The impact of misinformation on the COVID-19 pandemic. AIMS Public Health, 9(2), 262–277. https://doi.org/10.3934/publichealth.2022018

Dealing with propaganda, misinformation and fake news. (n.d.). Council of Europe Portal. Retrieved November 25, 2025, from https://www.coe.int/en/web/campaign-free-to-speak-safe-to-learn/dealing-with-propaganda-misinformation-and-fake-news
